Definition: In this task, you will receive public comments from online platforms. You are expected to divide the comment into two classes: identity attack and non-identity attack. Identity attack refers to anything that is rude or disrespectful to a person's identity, including appearance, race, gender and sexual orientation.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Silly Americans, laws are for poor people.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment contains identity attacks on Americans.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: More annoying drivel from plagiarist Wente.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is unrelated and does not contain identity attacks.

Negative Examples.explanation: This comment should be non-identity-attack because it is not disrespectful to any groups.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: The Canadian gang of fools at the table.
Negative Examples.explanation: This should be identity-attack because the comment contains identity attacks on Canadian.

Comment: Our form of government is a representative democracy.  We elect our representatives to propose and enact laws.  Rarely do the people vote directly on ANY issue.  The Initiative process is written in two phases so that citizens who want a law may show popular support, and then, if elected officials STILL won't enact it, take it to the direct ballot and pass it.  In SJC, within 120 days of filing,  a number of registered voters must sign such petitions equal to 15% of the voters in the last election for governor, so 1635 signatures. An all-volunteer group of 200  got 2365 valid signatures, roughly 22% in 30 days. The petition stated in the first paragraph that we hoped the SJCC would adopt the ordinance ASAP, which I for one am grateful they did.  

Direct democracy requires changing the Constitution of the USA and WA and the county charter.  That is a tall order.  The research and thought crucial to governing well takes lots of time.  Vote for good people to represent you.

Comment: This certainly is a weird market in the Vancouver area. I live in a rural Vancouver suburb and notice that the over $1 million homes, which most in my neighborhood  are, have pretty much stopped selling. They just sit on the market for months while the financeable sub $1 million places are still moving, if more slowly than a year ago. The weird thing is that the listing inventory is dropping daily.  This is especially noticeable in nearby Mission, B.C. where the foreign investor tax does not apply and the sub $500,000 houses are vanishing.  Mission is about an hour drive from Vancouver center.  Many new detached houses in Maple Ridge are priced around $800K to $900K, which seems shockingly high for this area.  It looks like prices are wanting to converge near $1 million for a detached house. Is this even possible so far from the center of Vancouver?  The next year should tell. Maybe there will be a flood of listings in the spring of 2017, but at this point that looks unlikely.

Comment: International agreements on refugees and our domestic law implementing those agreements per the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act provide for any person in Canada legally or illegally to make a claim for refugee status and if eligible entitled to a hearing before  the Refugee Protection Division.

Some refugees may appear Port of Entry and request protection while others enter Canada illegally and then subsequently seek protection. They are allowed to do so under the IRPA. As far as illegal entry of refugee claimants, the IRPA makes it clear at section 133 that enforcement sanctions and any criminal proceedings relating to illegal entry or false documents are to be deferred while a claim for refugee status is being determined. If determined to be a refugee then those proceedings are no longer on the table.

Comment: I do something similar with my Questrade account except I put a little spin on it.  It's $4.95 per trade flat fee so I like to save up at least $5K usually before I make a purchase.  Sooooo, in the meantime I use their Aggressive Growth Investor Portfolio IQ product (robo advisor) because I can transfer $250 a week into it with no transaction fees.  If you keep a min of $2K in there, they will just charge a .4% annual fee and will build a nice little basket of ETF's for you. Once I get it to about $7K I take out $5K and buy some shares in something...usually dividend paying stock. I also have all my dividend stocks set up on a DRIP so it constantly buys more shares with the dividends it earns without any transaction fees. 

I find saving my stock purchase funds this way keeps me in the market and provides some decent dollar cost averaging opportunities along the way. Of course, the market has been going up so this has been working particularly well but I have a long time horizon anyway

Comment: Myth #1: A positive urine test for marijuana establishes impairment. This mistaken conclusion is often argued in legal and worker compensation cases. Remember, the screening test detects a number of inactive metabolites, and the confirmation test solely targets the inactive metabolite THC-COOH. As Marilyn A. Huestis, PhD, of the National Institute on Drug Abuse pointed out: “[A] positive result in a urine test for cannabinoids indicates only that drug exposure has occurred. The result provides no information on the route of administration, the amount of drug exposure, when drug exposure occurred, or the degree of impairment.” (Principles of Forensic Toxicology. Washington, DC: AACC Press, 2010.)

http://journals.lww.com/em-news/Fulltext/2017/08000/Toxicology_Rounds__Five_Myths_about_Marijuana.5.aspx

Comment: 2 simple rules:

Buying a new car is for the wealthy (>$1 million net worth). If that's you, it's just another decision to buy consumables such as a vacation, expensive clothes, etc. If that's not you, you're spending money you can't afford (check your TFSA).

NEVER finance a vehicle. In the $13,000 car example, much better off to buy a $3000 vehicle, and SAVE the rest you would have spent on car payments until you can ladder up to something better.

PS. There is no such thing as 0% financing, and all the 'discounted' rates you see for new car financing are a lie. The government should compel car financiers to disclose the true cost, which is the interest, PLUS the premium you paid for the car by not purchasing with cash.

And if you want to see what cars are really worth, go to a car auction. They are in most major cities (eg. Adesa in Vancouver), it is how used dealers dispose of cars they don't want when you trade-in. The most disturbing fact is how little luxury cars sell for.

Comment: This company is a legal monopoly power producer that has its tariffs determined by government. It's financial performance has got nothing to do with the quality of management. Revenue is simply a function of tariffs (allowed by government) multiplied by watts of electricity used.  Admittedly operating efficiencies could be influenced by management but even the world's worst operators could look good as long as the government allows tariff increases. Management deserve no credit (or financial incentives) unless they can demonstrate CONTROLLABLE COST (i.e., independent of fuel cost) efficiencies per Watt of energy generated or sold). There is no indication that this was the basis of bonuses paid. 

This requirement in the context of Eskom, however, is very ambitious. I think most of the public would be happy to pay bonuses if fraud and looting was limited to the same or a little less than the previous financial year.

Most of our educators cannot teach at this level, and this is why larger class sizes hurt our system when larger class sizes assure proper funding. In the entire rest of the rich world - markets are extremely regulated (far moreso than here) - and I would argue, this is WHY they are rich countries. Laws alone can force markets to actually benefit society.

Comment: We don't have to deal with the road surface hazards faced every day by folks driving between the Valley and Anchorage. But we have to drive weekly to Wasilla and less frequently Anchorage. The stud-less tires on our Toyota serve us very well. I'll leave it to others to debate studs versus no studs. Whatever tires one has, prudent defensive driving under given road conditions (lower speed, greater spacing between vehicles etc.) is the single most important safety tool in preventing accidents.

I wonder if the uninterrupted parallel pavement grooves in the driving surface represent the greatest threat to the driving public, such hydroplaning in the summer. Last week driving home from Anchorage, we encountered some snow and ice on the highway. The conditions were easily dealt with by slowing to 50 or 55 mph. But the car was regularly tossed around by grooves in the pavement; very disconcerting. Perhaps we should focus on the assertion by some that DOT allows the use of inferior asphalt?

Mary Williams Walsh reported, "Unlike cities, states are barred from seeking protection in federal bankruptcy court. (http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/21/business/economy/21bankruptcy.html) No state (no, not even debt-plagued Louisiana), is "knocking at the door of bankruptcy courts" because it would be to no avail, especially so in Alaska's case since technically we are far from bankrupt. Also, Alaska has plenty of money for now in various funds stashed away to help us transisition to a sustainable state budget supported by broad-based taxes and subsidized by Permanent Fund earnings. We know what to do and have the resources to do it, for now. So we are not Louisiana, for now.

Comment: My family and I are one of the lucky ones in Vancouver that have "benefited" from increasing prices.  We are a family of 3 in our early40's, living in a nice area of Vancouver.  While on paper we are millionaires and have good incomes, we sure don't feel well off.  I wish that the government would look at it's taxation policy and start taking into account how hard it is for young families to get ahead and still enjoy life.   It seems there is a lot of money / resources directed towards seniors and the ultra-rich, but the middle class (which is still families making $200K+ family income in Vancouver) don't have a lot of focus.  I think we need to investigate removing the capital gain exception on homes, but allowing for mortgage interest deductions on income.  Also, taxing income on couples vs. sole income in keeping with what seniors have would help.  If we don't start focusing on the younger people, we won't have any left in our major centers.

Comment: China has issues with the rule of law, and human rights. But does anyone really care? The extradition treaty with China is unlikely to impact everyday Canadians. The only people that should be worried are Chinese citizens living in Canada.  So why do normal Canadians, those born here care?

I agree that some Chinese living in Canada might be innocent, but you have to assume that some accused of corruption or fraud are ACTUAL criminals. They defraud people in China, escape to Canada, and then defraud actual Canadians. The victims of extradition aren't even Canadian...

Obviously the chance of a Chinese criminal committing the same crime in Canada is small. But an extradition treaty does NOTHING that would hurt real Canadians. Yet, it prevents Canada from becoming a haven for Chinese criminals that might commit the same crimes against Canadians... if Canada gets more favorable trade terms with China out of this, its a Win-win IMO. Sucks for Chinese immigrants. But great for Canada.

Comment: Seattle has a benign climate, with breathtaking summers, and mild winters.  It is a globally acknowledged tech hub, with hundreds of small startups, in addition to goliaths like Microsoft and Amazon.  There is NO state income tax, the top tax bracket of 39.6% applies to singles with incomes of $418,400/couples $470,400US.  The City of Seattle (not affecting the suburbs) just assessed a further 2.25% on incomes in excess of $250,000.  Electricity is priced competitively, and is abundant.  Their sports teams have tasted success since Al Gore invented the internet.

BUT, its housing is unaffordable and getting worse, the cost of living is high relative to other jurisdictions, and its roads and bridges are clogged with traffic.

Comment: Gavin Hartford might have "decades of organisational experience in the labour movement and was active in the ANC at branch level and as an Eastern Cape Regional Executive Committee member", but it's no substitute for good writing. This piece had some very good points, but they were clumsily-articulated. The style and register was too close to that of a bad fiction novel. 

Flitting from first to second to third person and back is not recommended, generally, and is a literary technique which falls flat under any but the most careful hand. I would have edited the hell out of that piece, for the sake of maintaining standards. 

That said, Hartford does have a point. Zuma's grip on power won't be loosened quickly or easily, and the moment it is, he'll be off to Dubai to avoid standing charges.

Comment: A survey of Oregon voters in 2008 showed 76% overall support for a national popular vote for President.

Support was 82% among Democrats, 70% among Republicans, and 72% among independents.

In Gallup polls since they started asking in 1944 until this election, only about 20% of the public has supported the current system of awarding all of a state's electoral votes to the presidential candidate who receives the most votes in each separate state (not mentioned in the U.S. Constitution, but later enacted by 48 states) (with about 70% opposed and about 10% undecided).

Support for a national popular vote for President has been strong among Republicans, Democrats, and Independent voters, as well as every demographic group in every state surveyed. In the 41 red, blue, and purple states surveyed, overall support has been in the 67-81% range - in rural states, in small states, in Southern and border states, in big states, and in other states polled.

Comment: The Globe has so far published two experts on the matter of Catalonia's referendum. One was vehemently against the government of Catalonia, while this author seeks to paint the Spanish government as the problem. The truth is, both parties have handled the question of Catalonia's independence poorly.

In rebuttal to this author's views however, I must point out the following. The referendum called by the government of Catalonia was a 50% + 1 winner-take-all affair. The question was, "Do you want Catalonia to become an independent state in the form of a republic?" The vote required no minimum voter turn out to be official. And the order for the referendum was encompassed within a law that explicitly declared that Catalonia was an independent state if the vote was affirmative!

You don't have to be a scholar in constitutional law to see that the government of Catalonia acted in a reckless political way on a matter that demands the utmost in sober and measured steps.

Comment: Anybody with basic knowledge of the cannabis industry understands that it cannot possible be compared to other non-regulated industries. From a basic commerce/business standpoint, Eugene cannabis businesses have no reciprocity with cities that have retained the 1,000 ft buffer, or with other legal states that have a residency requirement, which Oregon's legislature decided to throw out (so basically, they can come here but Eugene's retailers can't expand or move our businesses there). So right off the bat, that makes them fundamentally different from other retail businesses. Cannabis' closest comparison is liquor stores, which do have state-wide a distance regulation, but OLCC opted to leave this to municipalities because they didn't feel they had enough data yet to make statewide restrictions. Store locations will be regulated, but it might be too late for the small, local businesses by the time state-wide regulation comes around.

Comment: Morality would be a meaningless and amorphous concept if there is no omniscient arbiter whose words and judgement are impartial, incorruptible, unambiguous and final. It is patently clear that that final arbiter cannot be subject to the same foibles as we are. In other words, he cannot be human. Additionally, we must be able to point to and reference a source or text where our moral compass derives it's definition so that we can discern and turn from error. The events of Charlotsville have illustrated how something can be perfectly legal and yet still be perfectly odious, reprehensible and immoral. It's immoral not because it's illegal but because the text of our moral code declares it to be so and our consciences confirm it to be true. It's the same reason why the Obergefell decision must be decried as the odious and immoral decision that it is, legal though it may be.

Comment: I do not think pot is a "tropical" plant. It needs lots of sun and not too much water. It's dies off in the winter and is replanted in the Spring.

When pot became a "problem" they burned down all the naturally growing pot so people down there started growing it in corn fields, in between the rows of corn. People who lived far away from cities grew it in their yards or under the trees in their orchards. 
It could grow outside up where the giant pumpkins and cabbages are grown if you started it inside and then moved it outside. 
I remember after the big farm crash in the mid-west when some of the farmers  were growing it as a way to keep their farms.

Comment: Kudos to the Globe for identifying the real problem --- the proposals and draft legislation are deeply, even fatally flawed.

However well intentioned the government was (and that is debatable) the proposals are rife with complexity and all manner of unintended consequences.

The problem appears to be that too much reliance was placed on bureaucrats and academics to frame the proposals.

There are much simpler ways to solve the problems that the government perceives with the existing rules.  For example, adjusting the capital gains inclusion rate to more closely align with dividend rates would eliminate pages of complex and harmful new proposals.  Professional corporations could be made ineligible for the small business deduction to reduce the deferral without resorting to raft more new provisions so complex that the government has not even been able to figure out how to draft them yet.

I urge the government to withdraw this legislation and start over.

Comment: I think Schill is trying to maintain a delicate balance between ensuring Shurtz has due process and being effective as the head of the UO. In any regard, know that the First Amendment right to free speech is not absolute. For example, private companies can fire employees for doing what Shurtz did. And, the Supreme Court and appellate courts have ruled that there are some restrictions to free speech for public employees, such as, how much the offending behavior (e.g., wearing blackface at a party) disrupts the workplace or negatively impacts the effectiveness of other workers. 

As to the question about second chances, the issue is getting a second chance at the UO, to continue to be a law professor, who has to teach students, advise and mentor them, work alongside colleagues, participate in faculty meetings and represent the law school in public events, etc. And, Shurtz's position, as tenured faculty, is not a right, it's a privilege that has to be earned but can also be lost.

Comment: Comments deleted for lack of civility are clearly noted in the thread. No stalking necessary.

The evidence for the link between warming and cyclones lies in basic physics. Cyclones are heat engines. They rely on a reservoir of heat to power convection and latent heat transfer. The more heat, the more likely the storm will intensify. AGW has warmed the oceans significantly.

Storm surge is likely the most dangerous impact of cyclones. AGW has increased sea level (and likely, the wind velocity of cyclones), which exacerbates the surge.

Extreme precipitation and flooding are yet another dangerous component of cyclones. The Clausius-Clapeyron relation clearly points to an increase in precipitable water potential as a result of warming. Warmer often results in wetter.

The term "cyclone" (more accurately, "tropical cyclone") is the generic designation for all cyclones, typhoons, and hurricanes. Different location, different name, but "cyclone" covers them all.

Comment: I work in an ER and see people coming in on a weekly basis for tooth abscesses. Note that these MUST be dealt with or the infection can spread - even into the brain. (I can't pull teeth - never trained and don't have the tools). These usually result from untreated cavities.

Dentists in my city charge about $250 to pull an abscessed tooth. This is beyond what many can afford. Thus these people are on a merry go round of antibiotics and pain meds. In the ER every 10 days or so. Each visit costs the system about $700. Treatment for a brain abscess would easily run into the tens of thousands of dollars.

Most of these rotten teeth are due to a history of neglect and lack of basic dental care.

I believe that universal dental (no cosmetic procedures need be covered) is the best answer.

Comment: Joel Banks, yes this observation is based on my 18 years of teaching university undergraduates, as well as the observation of pretty much everyone I worked with. It's a dirty secret none of us ever talked about publicly, but we all knew it. When we were accepting high school grads into our program, the names were provided to us in order of their high school marks, beginning with the highest average. Starting with those whose average was over 90%, the ratio of names reflecting Asian and Middle Eastern parents versus names reflecting European or North American parents would be about 20 to 1 or even higher. Get into the 80%er's, and the ratio would be lowered to about 8 to 1 or so. Get down further into the 70's, and the ratio would be 1:2 or more in favour of the kids with names signifying European ancestry. Of course, marks alone don't signify ability but, if you talked to the highest-scoring kids, they saw university as a great opportunity, well worth the hard work.

Comment: "Building safety is a provincial jurisdiction"

True.
But public safety is a matter for all levels of government and the feds may have a duty (they certainly have the right) to get involved when it's clear that lower-tier governments are not doing what is required.

In the case of unsafe development next to interprovincial pipelines and railways, the feds clearly have a role in keeping people safe. There should be a federally-mandated minimum setback from pipelines and freight railways for 'high-consequence' sites like schools, seniors' facilities, hospitals, transit hubs, arenas, high-rises, etc.

At this point there is no national standard in either Canada or USA. South of the border several states and municipalities have enacted sensible set-back requirements. In most cases these were implemented in the aftermath of a major incident. 

Canada has never had a catastrophic pipeline incident. The possibility of one seems to be the furthest thing from the minds of city planners.

Comment: Mr Poloz is encouraging growth, a practice which has brought great wealth to Canada. However it is now passe'. As Pickett and Wilkinson showed in their thoroughly well researched book "The Spirit Level", growth in the economy does not improve living conditions. Yes, it does in developing countries but not in developed countries. Growth is good for business.

In their search for the reason that some countries are better places to live, they discovered that in  "eleven different health and social problems: physical health, mental health, drug abuse, education, imprisonment, obesity, social mobility, trust and community life, violence, teenage pregnancies, and child well-being, outcomes are significantly worse in more unequal countries, whether rich or poor." They could not explain why this occurred but the data was solid over 23 developed countries. Namely the higher the income inequality, the poorer the living conditions.

So time to move from the economy to income inequality as a goal.

Comment: The idea that I may be doing the same job as a man and get paid less for it is outrageous.  But these gender gap figures are not really talking about the same jobs - they're talking about overall pay differences between how much men earn versus women in the workforce.  So the man might be an engineer and the woman a cashier, yes their pay scales would be very different.  But they're doing different jobs, and I would expect them to be paid differently.  

Thus most of this gender gap analysis for me is pretty bogus.  I do believe that in some jobs where men and women are doing the same work, women are discriminated against and paid less. Those should be investigated.  But the sweeping denunciation here does nothing for women who really are being dinged in the workforce.  Another example of skewed truth in the media - even if you can't call it a 'false fact'.

Comment: I have ordained ministers on both sides of my family. I was a confirmed Lutheran, and then spent a lot of time in charismatic Pentecostal churches growing up until my early twenties. 

I went through a very "anti religion" phase but I've since calmed down. I just want to see people learn. If you believe God is the source of creation then why not spend a lifetime discovering creation as it really is? The Bible is full of allegory and symbolism and if you want to derive meaning from it because you think it brings you closer to God - by all means do. Just don't ever assume you know or even can know all there is about the cosmos. It's always surprising and inspiring in ways we can't even fathom.

When I was a kid I was certain the earth was only 6,000 years old and "science" was fooling itself (what all the adults in my life told me). How absurdly wrong and closed-minded I was. The universe is much more amazing than that - God or not.

Comment: Lets stop lying to ourselves with older narratives
The number of new coal power projects approved by the Chinese government fell by an astonishing 85% last year, a new analysis shows.

In 2015, 3GW of new coal power was permitted per week. By the second half of 2016, that number had fallen to 1GW per month — the slowest pace in at least 20 years.

In total, 22GW of new coal capacity was authorised for construction last year, and only 6GW in second half — down from 142GW in 2015.

Earlier this year, China suspended more than a 100 planned and under-construction coal projects, the first time in the country’s modern history that the total amount of permitted coal capacity fell.

This comes just days after a Greenpeace analysis of official data showed coal consumption falling for the third year running.

Comment: We are fortunate in Canada to have breast cancer screening programs everywhere except Nunavut.. Canadian data shows that breast cancer mortality is reduced by 40% in all women and by 44% in women ages 40-49 years old (Coldman et al, J Natl Cancer Inst. 2014). Absolute mortality reduction was 9% lower in women who were screened . Ms Weekes does not do service to the benefits of screening and threatens to risk more women opting not to screen and lose the benefits of early detection. We know that mammograms are not perfect, which is why we strive to improve the detection of breast cancer through research in supplemental screening with digital breast tomosynthesis, breast MRI and breast ultrasound. The good news that Ms. Weekes did not focus on is that with improved access of the BRCA test we can save more lives in women at highest risk for breast cancer. Women need to know more about this kind of research and make informed decisions about their health.

Comment: First off, you have never worked in the field. That is obvious. 
Secondly, when you deal in death, and sickness, day in and day out, you end up talking to others about it. This is just human nature. 
Thirdly, you do NOTE the outliers. You do not talk about the normal things. When I was doing EKGs back in the 70s/80s, and then doing EMT, I DID talk to others about certain cases. And they stick out in your mind. 
I had one woman who had a radical masectomy, which back then was RARE. DURING and after the EKG, we talked for an hour about it. How she felt, what she went through, etc. 
Likewise, when I was interviewing with CU med, i had to think about a 17 y.o girl that came through ER. Car crash. Beutiful girl. Nothing apparently wrong, UNTIL you opened her mouth. She made me realize that I could not deal with children's deaths.

Comment: It depends on how the policy is written:

"Many life insurance policies, just like any other insurance coverage, come with certain exclusions that null and void any benefits should you expire in a certain way, i.e., suicide. However, there can be fine print attached to that exclusion. Some policies will pay benefits even if the policyholder committed suicide, but the policyholder would have had to committed suicide after holding the life insurance policy for two to three years depending on the carrier."

"Some policies come with a separate exclusion that addresses non-disclosure of mental health and/or drug or alcohol addiction/dependencies. If you have a history of serious depression and your life insurance carrier doesn’t know, you run the risk of eliminating any benefits if you commit suicide. Leaving out information like this allows insurance companies to deny benefits based on a contestability clause."

http://www.insurancequotes.org/life/the-truth-about-suicide-life-insurance/

Comment: Predicting the future is never easy.    We have some brilliant professionals that are constantly analyzing  potential future outcomes under a myriad of scenarios.    I'm sure the best are trying to be rational in their analysis, but it's difficult not to make a ton of assumptions without real time evidence.

Have you heard the term 'fuzzy logic' Motley?    It comes from software programs that instead of calculating a single course of action using a complex logic structure, it allow thousands of calculation to redirect a course based on the flow of the most current information.  (If we're talking about servo motors, those corrections are made in milliseconds.)

When we are trying to predict the future, it becomes increasingly more accurate the closer we get to our target date.   That's why I'm trying not to jump to conclusion about the consequences of this administrations actions so early in the term.

Comment: Gary Macleod gets it!  It seems like the more government tries to put the onus on the vehicle driver to watch out for pedestrians, the more pedestrian accidents we seem to have.  The reason, as Macleod suggests, it that such laws give pedestrians a false sense of security:  "Well, the law says that the vehicle MUST come to a stop as soon as I enter a crosswalk, so I will be OK!"  With the red light traffic cam, pedestrians will be even more emboldened, believing now that no one will run a red light, and they can cross as soon as the walk signal is on.  As a pedestrian, you STILL have to be careful:  look both ways (left, right, then left again), and try to make eye contact with drivers, just like we were taught in kindergarten.  You can be as bold as you wish but ultimately, if it's you vs. a two ton vehicle, you will always lose, no matter who has right of way.

Comment: "Since I am trained it logic..."

Must not have been trained very well, if you were then you would know that simply stating something is "not" is not a logical argument, so here we have yet another amusing example of you not adeptly using logic.

Premise: in the OJ case, a racist cop led to acquittal.
Conclusion: "If a racist cop arrests someone, no matter the facts, that person can not be convicted."

That's your faulty conclusion. Your error is in assuming the premise is a sufficient condition, when it was one of many conditions. Just because a racist cop in 1 case was one of the facts considered (as I said in my original comment, "I would guess they considered all the facts") in acquittal, doesn't mean that is the only necessary fact and it would be applied in all other cases. That is a form of affirming the consequent. I can argue you used another fallacy as well, would you like to try to name it, put some of that training to use?

Comment: "Greens with a mere 16% of the popular vote, now wield a power vastly out of proportion to their percentage of votes."

The Greens are wielding that power in our CURRENT system. 

I note you are conveniently omitting the fact that the Greens got 16.5% of the votes and yet they're getting only 3.5% of the seats. Though they might hold the balance of power, they're still short-changed for representation.

This not a partisan issue.

Federal conservative party in 1993 got ~16% of the votes and wound up with ~1% of the seats. 

The status quo might favor a party I support, but I can't defend that outcome.

And cut the fear mongering: there are plenty of examples of functional democracies that have proportional systems. 

At the provincial and federal level, we very typically have "majority" governance that is secured with <40% of votes. 

The "stability" the present system offers ONLY exists because the system often lets elected officials ignore the voting will of the majority of voters.

Comment: The Supreme Court of Canada gave us a trilogy of cases may years ago which set an indexed maximum cap for general damages for pain and suffering and loss of enjoyment of life.  That maximum, in 2017, is $ 370,510.00.  This number is understood to be the compensation for the "worst" injury one can suffer--which is generally understood to be quadriplegia in a younger person.  Extra damages are available if the injury requires nursing care, loss of earning ability, and similar amounts for losses or expenses caused by the incident.  It is exceptional in Canada for injured persons to win millions of dollars---if they do, the injuries are severe.  Now look at Mr. Khadr.  His experience, the Supreme Court said violated his rights, we have to accept that.  However, how do you get to $10 million dollars given the rules and law that apply to ordinary Canadians when they suffer catastrophic life changing injuries that cap out at 3.7% of what Khadr is getting? Comment: 'I remember in the 1970s when the "scientists" shouted from the rooftops, "an ice age is coming!"'

That may be what you remember, but what you're actually referring to was a myth circulating in the popular press at the time (and, unfortunately, continuing today as an argument against global warming). There were no scientists or science publications that claimed that an ice age was coming. There were a few papers that discussed atmospheric aerosols, which do have a cooling effect, and these were the likely sources of the myth, but there were no mentions of an impending ice age. The Clean Air Act 1970 resulted in decreasing aerosol emissions.

Comment: We're wandering afield with discussions into theoretical physics but I'll take the step and say that little of  theoretical physics or theology is democratic.  It does take years of study and money for funding - I'd hardly characterize the pursuit as leisure.  In earlier ages it was clerics, funded by the Church or certain patrons that were able to pursue these studies.  Today, while access to information is far easier, it remains a relatively costly pursuit and requires some talent - advanced studies are never open to all.  But, as we have seen, knowledge percolates slowly through society and we all grow because of that.  Feynman's playful "Q. E. D.: The Strange Theory of Light and Matter"  is evidence that even the most esoteric subject may eventually be brought to "the masses".

"The threat from the far right in Canada is real," Ryan Scrivens, one of the new report's authors and PhD candidate at Simon Fraser University, told VICE News. Comment: Sue Steinacher - There's an economic principle - instead of looking at the short-term for a small group of people, you look at the long-term for everyone. A 6% tax today will eventually need to be a 30% tax if we maintain the same level of State government we have today. How do I know that? I attended the budget brainstorming Walker had here in Fairbanks two years ago. The math worked out that, without oil revenues, every income producer in the State would need to pay 30% tax to support the current level of government services.

So, I did the math. Currently, I wouldn't be paying much under the income tax, but I already pay 25% to the feds. In 10 years, if oil decline continues and state services remain at current levels, we will all be paying 30%. That PFD will mean nothing to me at that point because, if my income remains steady, I'll be bankrupt and living in a ditch.

Reducing the PFD for three years won't kill you and it, along with cuts, will balance the budget in five years.

Comment: Few current observers seem to recall the wrath that greeted Bill Clinton’s ascension. To the left, “Clintonism” implies accommodation and calculation. For the One True Way to be restored, Clintonism had to be delegitimized.

That delegitimization ushered in the politics of party restoration at whatever cost, governance and country be damned. This led first to an attempted legislative coup in 1998 and then to a judicial coup in 2000. And to all the more recent outrages of birtherism, government shutdowns, delayed Supreme Court confirmations and, ultimately, the rise of a would-be autocrat as a party nominee. —Susan Faludi

Comment: John, the people doing biological research on killer whales are pretty happy about the transients and the offshore populations. The Northern Resident group is also doing well at over 200 members at last count, which is the number that the Southern Residents were at historically. The big problems are reproductive success, lack of pregnant females, and the issue of high levels of contaminants (PCBs, flame retardants, and more) that are carried in the blubber of the Southern Resident killer whales. When food isn't readily available, the whales draw from their stores of fat and the toxic chemicals come into their blood stream. This may explain the problem of orca calf deaths.

The transients seem to enjoy eating our harbor seals and the 2 species of sea lions in our waters. The offshore whales eat sharks, squid, and marine mammals so lack of salmon isn't as big a problem for them. The three groups of killer whales are seen as distinct species, with different languages, diet, and genetics.

Comment: BC - don't do it.  The only thing worse that first past the post is - everything else. There is no real change, and as a result, the public loses interest in the process.  It is a bad system.

Comment: Morguard and Hunt dealt with the enforcement of judgments between Canadian provinces, which under Canadian law have the jurisdiction to regulate enforcement of foreign judgments with respect to most areas of law. However, the Supreme Court specifically noted in Morguard the need in the modern world economy “to facilitate the flow of wealth, skills and people across state lines in a fair and orderly manner.” As such, these cases must be considered in assessing the issue of the enforcement of foreign judgments in Canada.
Canada’s lower courts have almost universally applied the Morguard principles of enforceability to judgments originating outside Canada’s borders. This extension of Morguard has considerably simplified the enforcement procedure for foreign litigants.

Comment: This is a simple case of tickets not being transferable.  When you buy a ticket, that ticket is for you--not your wife, your buddy, somebody you sold it to on the black market, or your brother.  Travelers are required by TSA to travel under their own name.  In this case, somebody bought a ticket for brother A and then thought they could use it for brother B.  For that to work, there would have to be a "name change" on the ticket.  This actually can occur in some circumstances, but you have to ask for it before you get on the plane (preferably well before).  If you sneak brother A onto the plane under brother B's name, you are (and should be) toast.

Comment: No one said we shouldn't have roads. 
Just that we should prioritize pedestrians, transit, and biking above private cars in funding and design of our public space. 
Currently we prioritize car traffic far above all else, making all other means of getting around extremely difficult. 
Continuing to do this is not sustainable. There is not and will never be enough money and space for everyone to drive. We have to invest our limited transportation funds in modes that are more energy and space efficient, and that are financially sustainable. That means putting money into bike and pedestrian infrastructure. That means not only allowing buses to use the roads, but dedicating them space so that they can function efficiently and actually be useful to people. 

I did not say to build special roads for commercial vehicles. I was placing them within a hierarchy of priorities, and suggesting that the gas tax they pay needs to be raised.

Comment: I will just say this, too. Much of that extended training for doctors is in all facets of medicine. The psychiatrist has had at least one rotation through endocrinology, cardiology, and surgery, etc. NP education is focused on one area. It makes sense that we do not take as long to complete our education. Some kind of externship/mentoring program/residency after graduation is also reasonable. But too many places do not have such programs in place.  NPs do have the same courses in Advanced Pathophysiology, Policy and Politics, and other "core courses", but as an NP student, I did not have to have rotations through other disciplines. In my undergraduate program, I completed clinicals in all aspects. But one can practice as an RN with an Associate's Degree. To take it up to the level of being able to diagnose, treat, and prescribe, the education is more focused. I am glad that an increasing number of facilities are seeing the need for some kind of residency

Comment: I've been driving the 2007 version of this car (335i) for 7 years and over 100K. if you use it as a 2-seater with the cargo platform down over the rear seats, you have a fabulous tourer with loads of luggage space -- even with the top down. We've driven to California and back twice -- top down when the sun shines, and still able to take it through a car wash (which I would never do with my soft top car). I rented a 428 convertible in Florida for a week this past spring. Nice car although a bit tamer and softer than I was used to (maybe the 440 has better driving feel?). Biggest ergonomic complaint is that BMW has switched back to putting the cruise control switches on the steering wheel -- a really dumb move. The third stalk cruise control on my older bimmers is so much more intuitive and easy to use without taking your eyes off the road. I'll probably look for one of the last 335s when it's time to replace mine.

Comment: "Catalonia may have legitimate grievances, and the Catalonian people may want to secede, but this referendum is not a democratic or responsible way to deal with those issues."

Agreed. A referendum requesting a mandate to DISCUSS secession would have been legitimate. But a yes/no binding referendum (with no minimum voter turnout!) on Catalonia's independence is not. 

If the constitution of Spain doesn't lay out a procedure for secession, then that procedure must be negotiated between the governments of Catalonia and Spain. The procedure must guarantee fundamental human rights, adhere to democratic principles and be fair to both parties.
